segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Welcome to the annual DEFCON convention. This meeting was held in exciting Las Vegas, Nevada from July 9th through the 11th, 1999.
This is videotape number 28, Introduction to Virus.
My name is Robert Lupo. Those of you who actually know me here know me as AntVirus.
I actually work for a company called International Networking Services based out of Sunnyvale, California.
I'm part of the security consulting team on this company.
Fly me to the moon. Sorry.
Been working with International Networking Services for a while now. Really, really great company. Very happy there.
They send me to fun places like this. Cool.
The day I got hired, I said, okay, here's the situation. I'd love to work for you guys, but I want to go to Black Hat and DEFCON.
They said, okay, sure. I said, I'm there. I'll work for you.
Okay, I think it's safe to start here. I think we hit the 3 o'clock mark.
Can we dim the lights a little bit?
Can everybody see that okay? Is it a little lighter?
I can take credit for that. It came with PowerPoint.
Karen, there's like 30 knobs back there. Which one takes what?
Does anybody know how to dim the lights?
Yeah, we'll just take out the lights one by one.
Well, you got the back ones.
Oh, hi, and welcome to the introduction to computer viruses.
My name is Robert James Lupo, a.k.a. Virus.
Let's see if we can get through this in 15 minutes and still have leftover for questions here.
Introduction. At the end of this presentation, you should be able to understand the basics of computer viruses
and how they affect the computer systems.
Basically, I'm going to go into a real brief, basic introduction on the different types of computer viruses.
I'm not going to go into a lot of depth.
I'll be happy to answer questions, but this is an introduction.
This is going to give you a grasp on how the computer viruses actually affect different systems.
We're going to cover the types of computer viruses.
I'm going to talk about fakes and false alarms in the world at this point right now.
And then we'll wrap it up with the conclusion and questions at the end.
We have boot sector, bioinfector, multiparty, and macro viruses.
Now, I saved macros for the end because it actually happens to be the one virus I know the least amount.
But it also happens to be what's mostly getting a lot of press in the world right now.
So I can tell you kind of what I know about them.
I don't play with them that often.
We're going to go over how they work and the different types.
Alright, boot sector viruses attack the master boot record of the hard drive or the floppy disk.
Now, to give you an idea of how easy it is to actually infect a floppy disk or a hard drive,
is if I have an infected floppy disk, I can put it in the A drive from my command prompt.
If I just do a directory of that C drive, I've instantaneously infected the hard drive.
The master boot record is divided up into three different parts.
We have the code, the flat partition info, and the flat allocation and the partition information,
Now, the code portion of the master boot record is what you see when you see syntax error,
stuff like that, or invalid drive, or stuff like that.
That stuff is all encoded in there.
These are all the little error codes.
This is what tells the computer how to boot up, how to access the partition information.
I want you to remember that portion.
How to access the partition information.
We're going to get into that in a few seconds here.
What the virus does is the virus will first copy the boot code on the drive to a different sector of the media.
Several viruses will copy to sector 7, 9, 12, 17, 22.
What I normally do is if I'm looking for a boot sector virus, I'll actually look at each sector up to sector 25.
I actually look for an absolute duplicate of the boot code.
If I see it on other sectors, that usually gives me an indication that I have a boot sector virus,
or have been infected at one time.
A really great tool to use for this is Norton Utility's disk editor.
It was my absolute favorite tool to do.
I'd actually go in and actually view the boot sector.
After it copies the code over to a different sector,
it then copies the virus code over the code portion of the master boot record.
At the end of the virus code, it actually points to different sectors.
Now here's the really interesting factor dealing with boot sector viruses.
It is completely 100% possible to have multiple infections at the same time.
Because different viruses will actually copy to different portions of the sector, different sectors.
I've actually been able to infect a system with three different boot sector viruses at the same time.
Then I run a virus remover software, and it'll get rid of one virus.
Then I run it again, and there's a second virus.
Then I run it again, and there's a third virus.
It has to go down layers.
It's very, very important that if you end up with a boot sector virus,
rerun the software again and verify that it has been removed correctly.
On certain viruses, for instance, the New York boot virus.
Anyone been hit by it in the last year or so?
One of the cool things with the, I mean, like the New York boot.
New York boot specifically just copies over the code, does it over to like sector 7 and 9, I think, and I think 12 also.
And one of the easiest ways to get rid of a basic boot sector virus is by booting up off a clean disk,
and with fdisk on it, and type in fdisk forward slash mbr.
And who can tell me what that does?
Well, you know, I don't like to use the word format.
All it does is says, I don't care what code is there, throw this code over it.
And we'll get into that problem right now.
The fat partition info of the mbr holds the data and partition information of the disk.
Basically, it's an interpreter about, like your directory string, you know, or your directory tree on where everything is.
Some virus encrypts this information, making it impossible to retrieve your data if you remove the virus incorrectly.
A monkey is such a virus.
What monkey does is it copies over the code, and then it encrypts all the directory information.
So you have to boot up.
The virus has to de-encrypt it, and then run the actual code.
If you type in fdisk slash mbr, you've lost everything.
As a matter of fact, I hate dropping names, but McAfee software actually has a specific remover only for the monkey virus.
This normal remover does not remove the monkey virus.
You actually have to download the monkey remover.
Get that monkey off your back.
What it does is it actually uses a de-encrypt key, and then permanently de-encrypts the fat partition information so it can remove the virus correctly.
Another way to remove a basic computer virus without doing fdisk slash mbr, it takes a lot longer, but it's just as effective,
is by using Norton Utilities' disk editor, and actually just copy the code that the virus moved over to another sector,
and just copy it back over again, and then get rid of the virus also.
Once again, fdisk slash mbr, awesome way to do it.
But be very, very careful about what virus you have when you do this.
The type of different boot sector viruses we have stealth, polymorphic, encrypting, and any combination of these.
Stealth boot sector viruses, they hide an upper memory, and they try to actually hide the virus code or hide the detection capabilities of the detection software.
Basically not letting you find it, which is why it's extremely important to boot off of a clean boot disk.
I've seen tons of people actually install a virus software and sit there and say,
I know I have a virus, but this software is not finding it, it must be a piece of crap.
Well no, what you're dealing with is a stealth virus that's hiding itself, and it's not letting the detector find it.
So if you boot off of a clean disk yet, it does not let the virus move into memory, allowing it to be removed correctly.
Almost all the boot sector viruses I've ever dealt with have at least a stealth capability.
Because once again, what's the most important thing for a virus?
It's to be able to replicate itself and move from one system to another without being detected.
Polymorphic boot sector viruses, another one of my favorites.
Polymorphic viruses are actually really tricky.
They change the code each time they replicate themselves.
So they're never quite the same virus twice.
Now, who can tell me what kind of a pain in the butt that can be?
Anybody have an idea of why that can be real difficult?
How about the fact that it's hard or impossible to write a specific remover for it?
Because remember, a remover is used, the way a remover for a specific virus is developed,
is they actually decompile or reverse engineer the virus when they get it into the company.
And they look for specific keys in the virus, and that's how they actually set up the data file to remove it.
Well, if it's never the same virus twice, you can't write a specific remover.
So what the antivirus companies came up with is what they call a simulator.
They run the specific simulator, and the simulator says, hey look, I'm accessing that disk.
And what the boot sector virus will do is say, great, I'm going to replicate myself.
And the moment it sees the code key, it stops the process, uses the code key to de-encrypt the virus and remove it.
Now, I don't know about you, but I'm impressed.
And I think I could be wrong on this, and if someone knows different, you can correct me,
but I believe McAfee was the one who developed that the first time.
They were the first ones to come up with the simulator.
I can't hear you, I'm sorry.
You weren't here when I was discussing the fact that when I worked at an antivirus company,
we would get on an average of 300 brand new viruses every single month.
And what we would do is we would take the viruses and reverse-engineer them
and break down the code and see how this specific version of the virus was working.
We had a whole team of programmers who would sit there and do nothing but just rip apart viruses,
just like people would rip apart different software to see how the software works.
The only difference is you don't get in trouble for ripping apart a virus like you do software.
Kind of interesting if you think about it.
Encrypting viruses will encrypt data or themselves, making it more difficult to remove.
They also make it impossible to recover data without the virus being there to de-encrypt it,
which goes back to monkey, which I told you about the partition information prior.
When you start compiling these together, when you start dealing with stealth, polymorphic, and encrypting,
you start dealing with some very, very nasty viruses.
Because it makes it conceivably and just immensely more difficult to remove.
You will find that you may come across a virus where no matter what remover you have won't remove the virus.
When I worked for this company, we would actually get people calling up and saying,
Hey, look, I've tried you guys, I've tried these guys, I've tried these guys, and I can't get rid of this.
And I'm getting this funky message that says that Wendy's a bitch.
And I don't know who Wendy is.
And my wife was kind of wondering who Wendy is also.
And what we'd do is we'd say, okay, here, send us a couple files and send us,
go into a diskette and format a diskette or access a diskette, send that in to us,
and we would try to detect the virus and find out what's going on.
A little side note here, something I thought that was actually interesting is,
if you walked into the company to the virus research area where they were actually doing the testing and checking the viruses,
there was actually a warning sign there saying images on the screen may not be,
I forgot how they basically put it, but basically not PC.
You may see things on the computer screens that may be offensive to yourself and you've been duly warned.
Because some viruses would actually show naked pictures of people's girlfriends or very foul statements in there.
So you'll sit there and be working and all of a sudden, my ex-wife's a bitch and there's a naked picture of her.
So they put that sign up there because a couple of women were walking by going,
he's got naked pictures on his thing, he's doing porno things.
He goes, actually, no, it's a virus, but I'm doing my job, it's cool, leave me alone.
Yeah, but you've been working on that virus for six months.
I don't like the virus, I don't know why.
Are there any similarities between viruses of this size and infection vectors?
Yeah, I'll get into that when we get into viral infectors.
How am I doing on time?
I'm almost half over and it's been 15 minutes, alright.
When you're dealing with viral infectors, the majority of viral infector viruses will actually vision the red portion there as just the basic vial itself.
And what the viral infector virus will do is it will sit there,
It'll sit here and put a marker at the beginning of the vial.
Ooh, you've got a laser pointer.
This portion right here would actually be a pointer for the virus.
Let's get away from the speaker.
And what it will do is this portion of the code will tell it to go to the very end of the vial and actually load the virus into memory here.
And the end of the virus code here actually tells it to go over here and launch the vial.
Now the problem with vial infector viruses is, who can tell me what's really obviously a problem with vial infectors?
So sometimes it's very important to actually get a disk image of your system.
And then what you can do is do like a binary compare of your image against your system and actually see if there's any differences in size.
Who can tell me right off the bat, what's the maximum size for a com file?
So what happens if you see a com file that's 1024?
Which is one of the most popular things for a virus to actually infect.
Let's see, that's a good one to do.
So by checking the size of the file, sometimes you can detect whether or not you have a virus.
A lot of the virus remover software doesn't cut off this code.
What it does is it'll kill the virus itself, deactivate it.
So it just basically says, just run the file and stop.
But it doesn't actually change the size of the file.
Now who can tell me what happens if you have a com file that's too big?
What effect does that have on your system?
Code gets put into another sector.
Which means is, yeah, you might have actually removed the virus.
You're in a lot of trouble.
Now, honestly, right now, I'd like to have a show of hands.
Who actually backs up their system?
Now, raise your hand if you weren't lying.
Backing up your system is immensely important.
Not just because of viruses, but for other reasons.
Viruses will do some serious damage to your system without a proper backup.
You're in a lot of trouble.
Especially if you finally just got Microsoft Windows 95 working.
I mean, without crashing and giving GPFs every 30 minutes and it's actually working.

is sometimes the virus will actually encrypt the file.
Which basically means you could maybe kill off the virus but then you lose the file.

Some people get really very fancy.

And some of these people who write these put a lot of time into them.
Which means you could probably be using this time for other things like cooking for your spouse.
Something a little bit more productive.
All in all, I'm still very fascinated by these.
And I'll tell you why after I take a sip of water.
I was in the entertainment software industry for seven years.
And I also worked in the real world software industry for several years other than the entertainment software industry.
My basic attitude is get it on the market, get it out there as quick as possible, make the money and move on to something else.
And I'll be damned if I'm going to worry about a virus or something.
Who can tell me right now what viruses are, most viruses are written for what operating system?
But keep in mind that the majority of the viruses that were written for DOS only work up into DOS 3.3.
So you really don't have to deal with them.
Back in the 3.3 days, my absolute favorite virus back then was the music boot virus.
Which was a boot sector virus that was actually very, very cool because you'd be working away, typing away, and all of a sudden your whole system would freeze.
And it would go doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, doo.
And it would then freeze and go back to normal.
You know, little PC speakers going off.
And then you'd sit there going, okay.
And you'd just work a little bit and you'd walk around and everything would freeze.
Doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, doo, doo.
And then it would unfreeze and you're going, okay.
And then you'd work a little while and then everything would freeze.
And you wouldn't hear any sounds and everything would be dead.
And you're going, now I'm really sure something's wrong.
Most people, when you get calls, I'm going, you know, I used to do tech stuff and have a lot of clients.
And every time they got infected with this virus, it's like, something's wrong with my hard drive and something's wrong with my motherboard.
And I'm going, you know, I could make a lot of damn money if I just didn't fix the virus.
Damn it, I have FX. I hate that.
Music boot virus only affects up to DOS 3.3.
When I worked at the virus detection company I worked for, and I know I'm going to slip out and tell you where I worked,
the place I worked, I actually came storming out of my office one time, cursing up a storm really pissed off
because I couldn't infect a machine with a virus.
And I had to stop and think about how really ridiculous that sounded.
I was like, damn thing won't infect my system.
Wait a minute, what's wrong with this picture?
At some point you're mad because you can't infect a system with a virus.
Multipartite viruses. I want to talk about this for a little while.
Who can tell me what a multipartite virus is?
Multiple infectors. What would it infect?
Yes, it infects both boot sectors and files.
Now think about a virus that infects both boot sectors, files, polymorphic, stealth, and encrypting.
Who wants to sit there and play with that?
No, actually I don't think I ever ran into a single one of those when I worked at McAfee.
Yeah, multipartites are very fascinating because they replicate faster than almost any other virus there are.
Because they infect the files and they infect the boot sector themselves.
Who can tell me a multipartite virus in the wild right now that's actually very active?
It infects both files, actually it infects the files directly, and it also hits the boot sector.
Now, the thing with these is they replicate so fast because you can infect a file, it infects your hard drive, it infects every single file that you have on your hard drive.
Some of them target specifically doc files, some of them target specifically executables and comp files, some target everything.
Anything that has any type of encoded string into it.
Which means you can spread them through email, you can spread them through the internet, through IRC.
Who here actually downloads files through IRC from people that they don't know?
Aside from this guy right here.
I'm telling you right now, do not ever, ever take a file from anybody that you don't know directly.
And then if you do know them, don't take that file unless you really analyze it.
At home I have a specific machine that is off my network that I transfer files to specifically.
I unplug the network and then I check out the file before I ever let it go anywhere else on my network.
How many times have I actually found the virus that way?
One of them completely wiped out my system.
And if it happened to be that Windows 95 box that I just got working real well, it would have been in bad shape.
Multipartite viruses are very, very nasty.
Because the virus detecting software actually has to track down where it's infected in the file and remove it from the boot sector.

you're going to find people going, hey, if I can do this, I can do that.
